column2: commit 7d252e9e7ea6cabc77b265946c1e880b7e766dd0
description (overwrite with mapped element)

## schema based on version 2.11.0: ## (.0 is an array element) (* is required) (+ denotes ontology term)

column2: ##An arbitrary identifier for the mcodepacket.
##An individual who is a subject of mcodepacket.
##A unique researcher-specified identifier for an individual.
##A list of alternative identifiers for an individual.
##One of possibly many alternative identifiers for an individual.
##A timestamp representing an individual's date of birth; either exactly or imprecisely.
##The age or age range of the individual.
##The phenotypic sex of an individual, as would be determined by a midwife or physician at birth.
##The karyotypic sex of an individual.
##An ontology term specified when more than one organism may be studied. It is advised that codesfrom the NCBI Taxonomy resource are used, e.g. NCBITaxon:9606 for humans.
##Whether a patient's record is in active use.
##Whether a patient is deceased.
##A code for a person's race (mCode).
##A code for a person's ethnicity (mCode).
##One or more conditions that occur with primary condition.
##An ontology term.
##An ontology term.
##Value representing the Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group performance status.
##Value representing the Karnofsky Performance status.
##A genomics report associated with an Individual.
##An arbitrary identifier for the genetics report.
##An ontology or controlled vocabulary term to identify the laboratory test. Accepted value sets: LOINC, GTR.
##The name of the organization  producing the genomics report.
##The date/time this report was issued.
##List of related genetic specimens.
##Class to describe a biosample used for genomics testing or analysis.
##An arbitrary identifier for the genetic specimen.
##The kind of material that forms the specimen.
##The anatomical collection site.
##Body side of the collection site, if needed to distinguish from a similar location on the other side of the body.
##Related genetic variant.
##An arbitrary identifier for the cancer genetic variant.
##The overall result of the genetic test; specifically, whether a variant is present, absent, no call, or indeterminant.
##The method used to perform the genetic test.
##The symbolic representation of an amino acid variant reported using HGVS nomenclature (pHGVS).
##The type of change related to the amino acid variant.
##The cytogenetic (chromosome) location.
##The cytogenetic (chromosome) location, represented using the International System for Human Cytogenetic Nomenclature (ISCN).
##A gene targeted for mutation analysis, identified in HUGO Gene Nomenclature Committee (HGNC) notation.
##A representation of an identifier for a gene.
##Official identifier of the gene. It SHOULD be a CURIE identifier with a prefix used by the official organism gene nomenclature committee, e.g. HGNC:347 for humans.
##A list of identifiers for alternative resources where the gene is used or catalogued.
##An alternative identifier from a resource where the gene is used or catalogued.
##A gene's official gene symbol as designated by the organism's gene nomenclature committee, e.g. ETF1 from the HUGO Gene Nomenclature committee.
##The symbolic representation of a genetic structural variant reported using HGVS nomenclature (gHGVS).
##The genomic class of the specimen being analyzed, for example, germline for inherited genome, somatic for cancer genome, and prenatal for fetal genome.
##The variation ID assigned by ClinVar.
##An ontology term.
##Related genomic region studied.
##An arbitrary identifier for the genomic region studied.
##The range(s) of the DNA sequence examined.
##An ontology term.
##The description for the DNA region studied in the genomics report.
##The gene mutations tested for in blood or tissue by molecular genetics methods.
##An ontology term.
##The ID for the gene studied.
##An ontology term.
##Range(s) of DNA sequence examined.
##The method of counting along the genome.
##An Individual's cancer condition.
##An arbitrary identifier for the labs/vital tests.
##Ontology class list
##An ontology term.
##An ontology term.
##An ontology term.
##An ontology term.
##A description of the cancer spread in a patient's body.
##An arbitrary identifier for the TNM staging.
##TNM type: clinical or pathological.
##The extent of the cancer in the body, according to the TNM classification system.Accepted ontologies: SNOMED CT, AJCC and others.
##Category of the primary tumor, based on its size and extent. Accepted ontologies: SNOMED CT, AJCC and others.
##Category of the presence or absence of metastases in regional lymph nodes. Accepted ontologies: SNOMED CT, AJCC and others.
##Category describing the presence or absence of metastases in remote anatomical locations. Accepted ontologies: SNOMED CT, AJCC and others.
##Cancer condition.
##A radiological or surgical procedures addressing a cancer condition.
##Description of radiological treatment or surgical action addressing a cancer condition.
##An arbitrary identifier for the procedure.
##Type of cancer related procedure: radiation or surgical.
##Code for the procedure performed.
##The body location(s) where the procedure was performed.
##An ontology term.
##Body side of the body location, if needed to distinguish from a similar location on the other side of the body.
##The purpose of a treatment.
##The explanation or justification for why the surgical procedure was performed.
##Reference to a primary or secondary cancer condition.
##Medication treatment addressed to an Individual.
##Description of medication use.
##An arbitrary identifier for the medication statement.
##A code for medication. Accepted code systems: Medication Clinical Drug (RxNorm) and other.
##A code explaining unplanned or premature termination of a course of medication. Accepted ontologies: SNOMED CT.
##An ontology term.
##The purpose of a treatment. Accepted ontologies: SNOMED CT.
##The start date/time of the medication.
##The end date/time of the medication.
##An indication that the patient is no longer living, given by a date of death or boolean.
##A description of tests performed on patient.
##A description of tests performed on patient.
##An arbitrary identifier for the labs/vital tests.
##The individual who is the subject of the tests.
##A code identifying the type of tumor marker test.
##The result of a tumor marker test.
##A clinician's qualitative judgment on the current trend of the cancer, e.g., whether it is stable, worsening (progressing), or improving (responding).
